item.title: Anti-diarrhoea drug drives cancer cells to cell death – Aktuelles aus der Goethe-Universität Frankfurt
item.description: In cell culture, loperamide, a drug commonly used against diarrhoea, proves effective against glioblastoma cells. A research team at Goethe University has now unravelled the drug’s mechanisms  of action of cell death induction and – in doing so – has shown how this compound could help attack brain tumours that otherwise are difficult to treat.

item.title: News – Xfce 4.16 released
MAPS.ME is gone. We must bring it back.
item.description: TL;DR: MAPS.ME got bought by a payments company and completely rewritten, I want it back. I will rebuild the original app and bring it back. Sign up for this email list to get the original version back. Or subscribe to this Telegram channel. On December 20th, 2020, version 2.0 of the MAPS.ME app got pushed to the Apple App Store. It is expected to land on Android in the coming days. This is due to the app being sold off to a South Korean payments company. What changed? Compare these two images.
item.author: (Ondřej Sojka)

item.title: Integrating Cloudflare Gateway and Access
item.description: We’re excited to announce that you can now set up your Access policies to require that all user traffic to your application is filtered by Cloudflare Gateway. This ensures that all of the traffic to your self-hosted and SaaS applications is secured and centrally logged.

item.title: WiFi 6 gets 1.34 Gbps on the Raspberry Pi CM4
C# 9 records as strongly-typed ids - Part 4: Entity Framework Core integration
item.description: So far in this series, I showed how to use C# 9 records to declare strongly-typed ids as easily as this: public record ProductId(int Value) : StronglyTypedId<int>(Value); I also explained how to make them work correctly with ASP.NET Core model binding and JSON serialization. Today, I’ll present another piece of the puzzle: how to make Entity Framework core handle strongly-typed ids correctly. Value conversion for a specific strongly-typed id Out of the box, EF Core doesn’t know anything about our strongly-typed ids.
item.author:
(About Thomas Levesque
Thomas Levesque is a French software developer from Paris.)

item.title: Introduction to quantum computing with Q# – Part 11, EPR Quantum Key Distribution
item.description: In the last two posts we covered quantum key exchange using the B92 and BB84 protocols. Both of those depended with their security on the no-cloning theorem. Today we are going to dedicate a third post to the topic of quantum key distribution, and this time around we will explore a variant of key distribution relying on the phenomenon of entanglement and quantum correlations.

item.description: After a short multi-part detour into the world of quantum cryptography, in this part 12 of the series, we are going to return to some of the foundational concepts of quantum mechanics, and look at the programmatic verification of Bell’s inequality.
